codeLabChallenge_lightBackpackMystery.qu.translation: #10: LIGHT BACKPACK a mystery color forever in a LOOP.

codeLabChallenge_whenCubeTappedMysteryBa.translation: #11: WHEN CUBE IS TAPPED, LIGHT BACKPACK a mystery color.
Try the challenge first, then tap NEXT to check your answer!

codeLabChallenge_whenCubeTappedMysteryAc.translation: #12: WHEN CUBE IS TAPPED, do MYSTERY ANIMATION.

codeLabChallenge_whenCubeTappedDriveSide.translation: #21: WHEN CUBE IS TAPPED, DRIVE one side of a square and TURN.
Try the challenge first, then tap NEXT to check your answer!

codeLabChallenge_whenSmileActHappy.quest.translation: #22: WHEN SMILE IS SEEN, ACT HAPPY.

codeLabChallenge_whenSmileDriveSide.ques.translation: #23: WHEN SMILE IS SEEN, DRIVE one side of a square and TURN.
Try the challenge first, then tap NEXT to check your answer!

codeLabChallenge_whenSmileActWinner.ques.translation: #24: SAY, "Smile!" WHEN SMILE IS SEEN, then ACT LIKE WINNER.

codeLabChallenge_peekaboo.questionSlide..translation: #25: Play Peekaboo. (WHEN FACE IS SEEN, ACT HAPPY. REPEAT FOREVER.)
Try the challenge first, then tap NEXT to check your answer!

codeLabChallenge_stackCubes.questionSlid.translation: Try the challenge first, then tap NEXT to check your answer!

codeLabChallenge_stackCubesTipOver.quest.translation: #27: Stack 2 Cubes, then tip them over.

codeLabChallenge_whenFaceSeenTurnAround..translation: #28: WHEN FACE IS SEEN, TURN completely around.

codeLabChallenge_whenFaceSeenActSurprise.translation: #29: WHEN FACE IS SEEN, ACT SURPRISED, then TURN completely around.

codeLabChallenge_whenFaceFetchCube.quest.translation: #30: Fetch Cubes: Start with cubes a couple feet behind Cozmo. WHEN FACE IS SEEN, fetch a Cube and bring it back. REPEAT FOREVER.
Try the challenge first, then tap NEXT to check your answer!

codeLabChallenge_whenCubeSeenSetBehind.q.translation: #31: Put Cubes Back: WHEN CUBE IS SEEN, have Cozmo TURN and set the Cube a couple feet behind him and return. REPEAT FOREVER.
Try the challenge first, then tap NEXT to check your answer!

codeLabChallenge_intruder.questionSlide..translation: #32: WHEN FACE IS SEEN, ACT SURPRISED, then FOREVER: LIGHT BACKPACK red, SAY, "Intruder!" and blink BACKPACK off.
Try the challenge first, then tap NEXT to check your answer!

codeLab.tutorial.slide_letsYouProgramCoz.translation: Code Lab lets you program Cozmo.

codeLab.tutorial.slide_tapBlockToSeeFunc.translation: You can tap a code block to see what it does.

codeLab.tutorial.slide_dragBlocksToMakeP.translation: Drag code blocks together to make a program.

codeLab.tutorial.slide_greenBlockFirst.translation: Always place a green flag BLOCK first. That way, the green flag BUTTON starts your program!

codeLab.tutorial.slide_challenges.translation: Check out Challenges and grow your skills!

codeLab.projects.confirmDeleteProject.co.translation: Are you sure you want to delete this project?

codeLab.projects.horizontalTab.horizonta.translation:
THE BEST PLACE
TO START CODING.
Simply snap together code blocks to create your first programs! Complete challenges to grow your skills.

codeLab.projects.verticalTab.verticalTab.translation:
TAKE YOUR CODING SKILLS
TO THE NEXT LEVEL.
With concepts like branching and loops, create complex programs with endless possibilties.

codeLab.projects.featuredTab.featuredTab.translation: Get inspired by the powerful programs you can create. Remix code blocks to jumpstart your own ideas!

codeLab.remixConfirmDialog.saveProjectAs.translation: Save this project as a remix?

codeLab.firstRemixSavedConfirmation.save.translation: You have saved your first Remix!

codeLab.firstRemixSavedConfirmation.remi.translation: Remixing the code blocks of another project is a great way to jumpstart your own ideas.

codeLab.saveModifiedSampleProjectAsRemix.translation: Do you want to save your changes as a Remix?

codeLabFeaturedProject_HotPotato.project.translation: When the music stops, don't get stuck with the hot potato!

1. This is a game for two players, plus Cozmo. 

2. Cozmo will ask you to place a Cube under his lift so he can tap it.

3. In this game, the "potato" is indicated by Cube lights. When it lands on you, the lights will first turn red, and then green when the potato can be passed by tapping the Cube.

4. When the music stops, careful not to be stuck with the potato!

codeLabFeaturedProject_TinyOrchestra.pro.translation: It's your own tiny orchestra, and Cubes are your instrument!

1. Before you begin, make sure your device's sound is turned up.

2. Place 3 Cubes in front of Cozmo.

3. After you start, the Cubes' lights will spin different colors. Tap a Cube to play its instrument. Tap again to change it.

4. Experiment with the different music you can make!

codeLabFeaturedProject_MagicFortuneTelle.translation: Shake Cozmo and have your fortune told.

1. After you tap start, when Cozmo has a "?" on his face, this means it's your turn to ask him a yes-or-no question.

2. Then shake Cozmo and listen to your magic fortune!

codeLabFeaturedProject_CubeWhack.project.translation: Whack that Cube! What's your high score?

1. Before you begin, place 3 Cubes in front of Cozmo.

2. Cozmo's backpack light will turn a color. Quickly tap the Cube with the matching color.

3. Tap as many matching Cubes as possible before the time is up!

4. Can you beat your high score?

codeLabFeaturedProject_FiretruckAlarm.pr.translation: Tick, tock! Timers are more fun when they're a Cozmo.

1. After you tap the start flag, a ten-second timer will begin.

2. Then count down to Cozmo's fire truck alarm!

codeLabFeaturedProject_LightShow.project.translation: Turn off the lights and groove to the music.

1. Before you begin, turn off the lights.

2. Watch as Cozmo's Cubes perform a light show while he dances to the music!

codeLabGlossary.block_definitions.descri.translation: Drive a distance of [X] millimeters at a speed of [Y] millimeters per second. Use a negative [X] distance to drive backwards. Max [Y] speed: 220 mm/s.

codeLabGlossary.block_definitions.title..translation: drive left wheel [X] mm/s, right [Y] mm/s

codeLabGlossary.block_definitions.descri.translation: Drive the left wheel at [X] millimeters per second and the right wheel at [Y] millimeters per second. Use negative [X]/[Y] speed to rotate wheels counter-clockwise. Max speed: [X]/[Y] 220 mm/s.
Stop any current movement on the selected motor(s).

Navigate Cozmo to a position relative to his current position: [X] millimeters to the front, [Y] millimeters to the side, and angled at [Z] degrees. A negative [X] forward value moves him backward. A positive [Y] side value moves him right, while a negative moves him left. A positive [Z] angle turns him right, and a negative turns him left. Cozmo will use his path planner to try to avoid obstacles.

codeLabGlossary.block_definitions.title..translation: navigate in world to [X] x, [Y] y, [Z] °

codeLabGlossary.block_definitions.descri.translation: ADVANCED CODE BLOCK. Navigate Cozmo to a coordinate within his world map: [X] millimeters on the x-axis, [Y] millimeters on the y-axis, and facing a [Z] degree angle. Cozmo will use his path planner to try to avoid obstacles. Tip: This can be used to precisely map where you would like Cozmo to go. Note that because the origin point of Cozmo's internal map is something he controls (and not you), this code block is often most useful once you've calculated the relative distance between points you'd like him to navigate.
Turn [X] degrees at a speed of [Y] degrees per second. A positive [X] angle turns him right, and a negative turns him left. Max [Y] speed: 200 °/s.

Make Cozmo drive to a specific Cube and dock with it, which means he will get in position to be able to pick up the Cube but without raising his lift. Tip: Cozmo must see the specific Cube in order to dock with it, so it is often useful to do a check with the "is Cube [#] visible" sensor. Cube 1: looks like a paper clip. Cube 2: looks like a lamp or heart. Cube 3: looks like a baby in a baby seat.

Move the lift to [X] percent of max (0% = bottom, 100% = top) at a speed to [Y] degrees per second. Note: the lift uses an angular speed because the its arm is technically rotating. Max [Y] speed: 200 °/s.

Move the lift at a speed to [X] degrees per second. It will keep moving until stopped, or until min/max height reached. Note: the lift uses an angular speed because the its arm is technically rotating. Max [X] speed: 200 °/s.
Move the head to [X] degrees (-25° = max down, 0° = level, 45° = max up) at a speed of [Y] degrees per second. Max [Y] speed: 150 °/s.
Set Cozmo's backpack lights to the specified color. Use black to turn off the lights.
Make Cozmo speak the specified [text].

Set the specified edge [1, 2, 3, 4 or all 4 at once] of the specified Cube [#] to [color]. Use black to turn off the lights. Tip: Cube 1: looks like a paper clip. Cube 2: looks like a lamp or heart. Cube 3: looks like a baby in a baby seat.

On Cube [1, 2, or 3], [spin or blink] lights in [color]. The color black indicates " lights off ". Tip: Cube 1: looks like a paper clip. Cube 2: looks like a lamp or heart. Cube 3: looks like a baby in a baby seat.
Play the specified animation on Cozmo. If you would like to lock his wheels, lift, or head, use the enable/disable animation blocks.

ADVANCED CODE BLOCK. This block provides animation names on their own, able to be used to set a variable. Tip: Using the "play [animation name] animation" block, drag out the [animation name] and replace it with a variable. Then you can have the flexibility to set that variable to whichever animation you'd like depending on the conditions.
If you have previously disabled Cozmo's wheels, head, or lift during animations, use this block to turn them on again. Cozmo's wheels, head, and lift are enabled by default.

Disable Cozmo's wheels, head, or lift during all animations from now on, until the are enabled. Tip: This block can be useful if your project depends on Cozmo being aligned in a certain way. For example, if you want Cozmo to play a happy animation, but it's important he stays aligned to tap on a Cube, you can disable his wheels.

Clear all pixels on the current pending image for Cozmo's face. Note that this does not immediately turn off all pixels on Cozmo's face. To do that, use this code block, then "display on Cozmo's face".
Display the pending image on Cozmo's face. Note that the image will stay on Cozmo's face for 30 seconds unless interrupted (by an animation, the program ending, another image being displayed, etc.).
Sets the drawing mode for whether you are adding or erasing pixels. Tip: to see what you're drawing, use the "display on Cozmo's face" block.
Set how large the text on Cozmo's face is to [X] percent. 100% is the default size. Tip: to see what you're drawing, use the "display on Cozmo's face" block.

Aligns the text on Cozmo's face. [top/center/bottom] places the text in that alignment relative to Cozmo's face. [left/center/right] determines the text's alignment relative to the text position you've set with the "draw text at" block. For example, to draw text coming from the right side of Cozmo's face, set text alignment to "right", and in the "draw text at" block set the [X] value to 127 pixels. Tip: to see what you're drawing, use the "display on Cozmo's face" block.

Draw the specified [text] at the given pixel position, using [X],[Y] coordinates. Cozmo's face screen is 128 pixels wide and 64 pixels tall, so the visible [X] range is 0-127 and the visible [Y] range is 0-63. Coordinate 0,0 starts at the top left corner of Cozmo's face screen. Tip: to see what you're drawing, use the "display on Cozmo's face" block.

Draw a line between the 2 pixel coordinates. Cozmo's face screen is 128 pixels wide and 64 pixels tall, so the visible [X] range is 0-127 and the visible [Y] range is 0-63. Tip: to see what you're drawing, use the "display on Cozmo's face" block.

Draw a filled rectangle between the 2 pixel coordinates. Cozmo's face screen is 128 pixels wide and 64 pixels tall, so the visible [X] range is 0-127 and the visible [Y] range is 0-63. Tip: to see what you're drawing, use the "display on Cozmo's face" block.

Draw a rectangle between the 2 pixel coordinates. Cozmo's face screen is 128 pixels wide and 64 pixels tall, so the visible [X] range is 0-127 and the visible [Y] range is 0-63. Tip: to see what you're drawing, use the "display on Cozmo's face" block.

Draw a circle at the given [X],[Y] pixel coordinate with the given [Z] radius in pixels. Cozmo's face screen is 128 pixels wide and 64 pixels tall, so the visible [X] range is 0-127 and the visible [Y] range is 0-63. Tip: to see what you're drawing, use the "display on Cozmo's face" block.

Draw a filled circle at the given [X],[Y] pixel coordinate with the given [Z] radius in pixels. Cozmo's face screen is 128 pixels wide and 64 pixels tall, so the visible [X] range is 0-127 and the visible [Y] range is 0-63. Tip: to see what you're drawing, use the "display on Cozmo's face" block.

This block triggers when the green flag (start) button is tapped. Note that tapping the green flag button does two things: 1) Triggers all "when green flag clicked" blocks, and 2) Makes the other Event category blocks able to be triggered. For example, as you're working on your project and the green flag button isn't active, if Cozmo sees your face, a "when face is seen" block WON'T be triggered. Once the green flag button is tapped and is active, if Cozmo sees your face, a "when face is seen" block WILL be triggered.
Triggers this code block and runs the code blocks underneath it every time Cozmo sees a face. Note that the green flag (start) button must be active for this block to trigger.
Triggers this code block and runs the code blocks underneath it every time Cozmo sees a happy face. Note that the green flag (start) button must be active for this block to trigger. Tip: Smile big!

Triggers this code block and runs the code blocks underneath it every time Cozmo sees a sad face. Note that the green flag (start) button must be active for this block to trigger. Tip: Make a particularly upset frown.
Triggers this code block and runs the code blocks underneath it every time Cozmo sees a Cube.
Triggers this code block and runs the code blocks underneath it every time the specified Cube [#] is tapped.

Triggers this code block and runs the code blocks underneath it every time the specified Cube [#] is moved. Tip: Moving a Cube means placing it in a slightly different position or location. Tapping a Cube means giving it a deliberate, quick tap.
Triggers this code block and runs the code blocks underneath it whenever another code block broadcasts the corresponding message. Tip: For experienced coders, think of messages like functions.

Broadcasts (sends) a message to trigger the "when [message#] received" block. Tip: After broadcasting a message, the blocks under this block will continue to execute. Therefore, both this original stack of blocks and the blocks underneath the "when [message#] received" block will run in parallel. For experienced coders, think of this like starting a new thread in most programming languages.

Broadcasts (sends) a message to trigger the "when [message#] received" block, and then waits for the blocks under the "when [message#] received" to fully execute before continuing on. Tip: For experienced coders, think of this like a function call in most programming languages.

Wait [X] seconds. Troubleshooting: Does a project end before you're expecting it to? If no code blocks are executing, a project will automatically end after a few seconds. Imagine you're waiting for the player to tap a Cube, and you want them to be able to have more than a few seconds before the project stops running. Adding a "wait" block can make sure your project doesn't end before you want it to.
Repeat the enclosed code [X] times.

Repeat the enclosed code forever until program is stopped. Troubleshooting: Seeing your code run slowly? Try adding a short "wait" block to your forever loop. Sometimes the code can use a moment to catch its breath.
If the (condition) is true, then do the blocks in [A].
If the (condition) is true, then do the blocks in [A], otherwise do the blocks in [B].
Wait until the (condition) evaluates to true.

Repeat forever until the (condition) evaluates to true. Troubleshooting: Seeing your code behaving slowly? Try adding a short "wait" block to your forever loop. Sometimes the code can use a moment to catch its breath.
Use this block to either stop [all] code blocks in the entire project, or to stop [this script] and end all code blocks in the current stack of blocks.

codeLabGlossary.block_definitions.title..translation: enable: always wait for Cozmo to finish

codeLabGlossary.block_definitions.descri.translation: Enable automatically waiting for Cozmo to complete what he's doing before moving onto the next block. Note: This is the default behavior.

codeLabGlossary.block_definitions.title..translation: disable: always wait for Cozmo to finish

codeLabGlossary.block_definitions.descri.translation: Disable automatically waiting for Cozmo to complete what he's doing before moving onto the next block.

codeLabGlossary.block_definitions.title..translation: wait for Cozmo to finish [what Cozmo's doing]

codeLabGlossary.block_definitions.descri.translation: Wait for Cozmo to complete [driving/moving head/moving lift/animations/saying text/everything] before moving onto the next block.
Stop what Cozmo's doing: [driving/moving head/moving lift/animations/saying text/everything].

ADVANCED CODE BLOCK. Returns the [X], [Y] or [Z] component of Cozmo's world position, using Cozmo's internal map. Tip: This can be used with the "navigate in world to [X] x, [Y] y, [Z] °" block to precisely map where you would like Cozmo to go. Note that because the origin point of Cozmo's internal map is something he controls (and not you), this code block is often most useful once you've calculated the relative distance between points you'd like him to navigate.
Returns the angle, in degrees, that Cozmo is tilted forwards/backwards. Forward values are negative, backward values are positive.
Returns the angle, in degrees, that Cozmo is tilted right/left. Right values are positive, left values are negative.
Returns the angle that Cozmo is facing right/left. Right values are positive, left values are negative.
The height of Cozmo's lift as a % of its maximum (100%) height.
Returns the angle of Cozmo's head in degrees. (-25° = max down, 0° = level, 45° = max up)
Returns "true" or "false" depending on if Cozmo is currently picked up (floating in the air).
Returns "true" or "false" depending on if Cozmo currently sees a face.
Returns the name of the face (i.e. the name entered in Meet Cozmo). Returns a zero-length string if he sees a face he doesn't recognize.

If a face is visible, returns the [X] or [Y] component of the 2D position of the center of the face in Cozmo's camera view. (Cozmo's camera's range: 0,0 to 320,240) Tip: Try using face position as an input. If you move to the left or right, how would you like Cozmo to react?

ADVANCED CODE BLOCK. If a face is visible, returns the [X], [Y], or [Z] (height) position in Cozmo's world. Note that the origin point of Cozmo's internal map is something he controls (and not you). This is useful for determining the relationship between objects in Cozmo's world.
The current expression on a visible face. Returns a string of "happy", "upset" and "unknown".
Returns [1/2/3] corresponding to the last Cube tapped. Cube 1: looks like a paper clip. Cube 2: looks like a lamp or heart. Cube 3: looks like a baby in a baby seat.
Returns "true" or "false" depending on if a specified Cube was tapped. Cube 1: looks like a paper clip. Cube 2: looks like a lamp or heart. Cube 3: looks like a baby in a baby seat.
Cube [1,2,3] for setting variables.

Returns "true" or "false" depending on if a specified Cube is visible. Note that a Cube being visible means that Cozmo can clearly see its marker, so the entire Cube needs to within his line of sight and not too close, and the lighting conditions must be not too bright or dark. Cube 1: looks like a paper clip. Cube 2: looks like a lamp or heart. Cube 3: looks like a baby in a baby seat.

If the specified Cube is visible, returns the [X] or [Y] component of the 2D position of the center of the Cube in Cozmo's camera view. (Cozmo's camera's range: 0,0 to 320,240) Cube 1: looks like a paper clip. Cube 2: looks like a lamp or heart. Cube 3: looks like a baby in a baby seat.

ADVANCED CODE BLOCK. If a specified Cube is visible, returns the [X], [Y], or [Z] (height) position in Cozmo's world map. Note that the origin point of Cozmo's internal map is something he controls (and not you). This is useful for determining the relationship between objects in Cozmo's world. Cube 1: looks like a paper clip. Cube 2: looks like a lamp or heart. Cube 3: looks like a baby in a baby seat.

Returns the angle, in degrees, of the specified Cube's tip forwards/backwards as seen in Cozmo's camera. Note that this requires Cozmo to see the Cube. Cube 1: looks like a paper clip. Cube 2: looks like a lamp or heart. Cube 3: looks like a baby in a baby seat.

Returns the angle, in degrees, of the specified Cube's tilt right/left as seen in Cozmo's camera. Note that this requires Cozmo to see the Cube. Cube 1: looks like a paper clip. Cube 2: looks like a lamp or heart. Cube 3: looks like a baby in a baby seat.

Returns the angle, in degrees, of the Cube facing right/left (as if flat on a surface) as seen in Cozmo's camera. Note that this requires Cozmo to see the Cube. Cube 1: looks like a paper clip. Cube 2: looks like a lamp or heart. Cube 3: looks like a baby in a baby seat.
The angle, in degrees, that the mobile device is tilted forward/backwards.
The angle, in degrees, that the mobile device is tilted right/left.
The angle, in degrees, that the mobile device is facing right/left (as if flat on a surface).
Returns current [year/month/date/day-of-week/hour/minute/second].
Returns the sum of [X] plus [Y].
Returns [X] minus [Y].
Returns [X] multiplied by [Y].
Returns [X] divided by [Y].
Returns a random integer (whole number) between [X] and [Y].
True if [X] is less than [Y].
True if [X] is equal to [Y].
True if [X] is greater than [Y].
True if both (X) and (Y) sub-conditions are true.
True if either the (X) or (Y) sub-conditions are true.
True if (Y) is false, false if (Y) is true.
Concatenate (combine) 2 strings of text together. For example: "Cozmo" and "says" becomes "Cozmosays".

Returns the [#] letter of the given string of text. For example the #1 letter of "Cozmo" is "C". Advanced Coder Tip: It's possible to creatively use strings and this block to make and navigate a list.
The length of the given string of text.
True if the second string of text is contained within the first string of text. For example, it is true "coz" is contained inside of "cozmo".
The modulo division of [X] and [Y] (i.e. what's the remainder if you divide [X] by [Y]).
Round [X] to nearest integer value (whole number), up or down.

Standard math operators: think operators that would be found on a scientific calculator. [abs] = absolute value of [X], [floor] = floor of [X], [ceiling] = ceiling of [X], [sqrt] = square root of [X], [sin] = sine of [X], [cos] = cosine of [X], [tan] = tangent of [X], [asin] = inverse of sine of [X], [acos] = inverse of cosine of [X], [atan] = inverse of tangent of [X], [ln] = natural logarithm of [X], [log] = logarithm of [X], [e^] = e to the power of [X], [10^] = 10 to the power of [X].

ADVANCED CODE BLOCK. The Cozmo python SDK provides access to hundreds more of Cozmo's animations. The animation's id string can be played using this block. Learn more about the SDK at developer.anki.com.

ADVANCED CODE BLOCK. The Cozmo python SDK provides access to hundreds more of Cozmo's animations. The animation group's id string can be played using this block. Learn more about the SDK at developer.anki.com.
Play the [sound name] sound.
Play the [sound name] sound and wait for it to complete.
Stop the [sound name] sound. Tip: To turn off Code Lab's default background music, stop "background" sound.

codeLab.export_modal.body.translation:
Submit your project to be Featured!

Copy it to Google Drive, then visit go.anki.com/submission to submit!

codeLab.export_modal_kindle.body.translation:
Open Device Menu to export your project.

Visit go.anki.com/submission for a chance to have your projects featured!

codeLabSampleProject_LaserSmile.variable.translation: The goal is to turn that frown upside down!
Smile to shoot your laser! Move your head to aim.
